blocks.name: congr
blocks.content: Definition of congruence by integer multiple (see ProofWiki "Congruence (Number Theory)", 11-Jul-2021, ~ https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Definition:Congruence_(Number_Theory) ): An integer ` A ` is congruent to an integer ` B ` modulo ` M ` if their difference is a multiple of ` M ` . See also the definition in [ApostolNT] p. 104: "... ` a ` is congruent to ` b ` modulo ` m ` , and we write ` a == b ` (mod ` m ` ) if ` m ` divides the difference ` a - b ` ", or Wikipedia "Modular arithmetic - Congruence", ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_arithmetic#Congruence , 11-Jul-2021,: "Given an integer n > 1, called a modulus, two integers are said to be congruent modulo n, if n is a divisor of their difference (i.e., if there is an integer k such that a-b = kn)". (Contributed by AV, 11-Jul-2021.)
blocks.origin:
thm congr(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz), wcel(c2, cn)), wb(wceq(co(c0, cmo, c2), co(c1, cmo, c2)), wrex(s0, cz, wceq(co(cv(s0), cmul, c2), co(c0, cmin, c1)))))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
} = {
  bitrd(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz), wcel(c2, cn)), wceq(co(c0, cmo, c2), co(c1, cmo, c2)), wrex(s0, cz, wceq(co(cv(s0), cmul, c2), co(c0, cmin, c1))), wbr(c2, cdvds, co(c0, cmin, c1)))
  3coml(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz), wcel(c2, cn), wb(wceq(co(c0, cmo, c2), co(c1, cmo, c2)), wbr(c2, cdvds, co(c0, cmin, c1))))
  moddvds(c2, c0, c1)
  syl2anc(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz), wcel(c2, cn)), wb(wbr(c2, cdvds, co(c0, cmin, c1)), wrex(s0, cz, wceq(co(cv(s0), cmul, c2), co(c0, cmin, c1)))), wcel(c2, cz), wcel(co(c0, cmin, c1), cz))
  nnzd(c2, w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz), wcel(c2, cn)))
  simp3(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz), wcel(c2, cn))
  3adant3(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz), wcel(c2, cn), wcel(co(c0, cmin, c1), cz))
  zsubcl(c0, c1)
  divides(s0, c2, co(c0, cmin, c1))
  diff.co.s(s0, c0, cmin, c1)
  diff.cmin.s(s0)
}

thm congr(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  ⊢ ((c0 ∈ ℤ ∧ c1 ∈ ℤ ∧ c2 ∈ ℕ)→((c0[mod]c2)=(c1[mod]c2)↔ ∃(s0 ∈ ℤ,(s0[×]c2)=(c0[-]c1))))
  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
  ⊣ d(s0, c1)
  ⊣ d(s0, c2)
} = {
  bitrd((c0 ∈ ℤ ∧ c1 ∈ ℤ ∧ c2 ∈ ℕ), (c0[mod]c2)=(c1[mod]c2), ∃(s0 ∈ ℤ,(s0[×]c2)=(c0[-]c1)), c2[||](c0[-]c1))
  3coml(c0 ∈ ℤ, c1 ∈ ℤ, c2 ∈ ℕ, ((c0[mod]c2)=(c1[mod]c2)↔ c2[||](c0[-]c1)))
  moddvds(c2, c0, c1)
  syl2anc((c0 ∈ ℤ ∧ c1 ∈ ℤ ∧ c2 ∈ ℕ), (c2[||](c0[-]c1)↔ ∃(s0 ∈ ℤ,(s0[×]c2)=(c0[-]c1))), c2 ∈ ℤ, (c0[-]c1)∈ ℤ)
  nnzd(c2, (c0 ∈ ℤ ∧ c1 ∈ ℤ ∧ c2 ∈ ℕ))
  simp3(c0 ∈ ℤ, c1 ∈ ℤ, c2 ∈ ℕ)
  3adant3(c0 ∈ ℤ, c1 ∈ ℤ, c2 ∈ ℕ, (c0[-]c1)∈ ℤ)
  zsubcl(c0, c1)
  divides(s0, c2, (c0[-]c1))
  diff.co.s(s0, c0, cmin, c1)
  diff.cmin.s(s0)
}

blocks.name: divgcdcoprm0

blocks.name: divgcdcoprmex
blocks.content: Integers divided by gcd are coprime (see ProofWiki "Integers Divided by GCD are Coprime", 11-Jul-2021, ~ https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Integers_Divided_by_GCD_are_Coprime ): Any pair of integers, not both zero, can be reduced to a pair of coprime ones by dividing them by their gcd. (Contributed by AV, 12-Jul-2021.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: cncongr
blocks.content: Cancellability of Congruences (see ProofWiki "Cancellability of Congruences, ~ https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Cancellability_of_Congruences , 10-Jul-2021): Two products with a common factor are congruent modulo a positive integer iff the other factors are congruent modulo the integer divided by the greates common divisor of the integer and the common factor. See also Theorem 5.4 "Cancellation law" in [ApostolNT] p. 109. (Contributed by AV, 13-Jul-2021.)

blocks.name: cncongrcoprm
blocks.content: Corollary 1 of Cancellability of Congruences: Two products with a common factor are congruent modulo an integer being coprime to the common factor iff the other factors are congruent modulo the integer. (Contributed by AV, 13-Jul-2021.)
